Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (proximate cause principles applied to duty)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: The inoperative smoke detector directly resulted in Plaintiff’s lack of timely notice of the first-floor fire, which caused Plaintiff to be exposed to smoke and to suffer smoke inhalation, medical treatment, lost wages, and property damage.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: Palsgraf addresses the scope of duty and foreseeability in negligence, not a causal chain involving an inoperative smoke detector and resulting injuries. The proposition is about factual and proximate causation in a premises/fire context, whereas Palsgraf focuses on whether the defendant owed a duty to the specific plaintiff and explicitly brackets off issues of proximate cause and damages. Thus, the case does not establish or affirm the specific causal proposition claimed; at most it provides a general framework about duty and foreseeability, not direct support for the stated causal conclusion.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The law of causation, remote or proximate, is thus foreign to the case before us. The question of liability is always anterior to the question of the measure of the consequences that go with liability. If there is no tort to be redressed, there is no occasion to consider what damage might be recovered if there were a finding of a tort… The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension.”

Polsby v. Samuelson.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the common areas of the Premises reasonably safe, to maintain safety devices (including smoke detectors) in operating condition, and to take reasonable steps to warn tenants of hazardous conditions.

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (foreseeability/proximate cause).
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: Plaintiff relies on the following representative statutory and case authorities in support of the legal propositions in this Complaint, including the duty to maintain safety devices, proximate cause, foreseeability, and landlord/possessor responsibilities.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: Palsgraf is a leading case on duty, foreseeability, and the relational nature of negligence, not on statutory duties to maintain safety devices or on landlord/possessor responsibilities. While it does touch on proximate cause and foreseeability, it ultimately holds there was no duty to this plaintiff and expressly says the law of proximate cause is "foreign to the case." Thus it only partially aligns with the proposition and does not affirm the broader landlord/safety-device duties claimed.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: The conduct of the defendant’s guard, if a wrong in its relation to the holder of the package, was not a wrong in its relation to the plaintiff, standing far away. Relatively to her it was not negligence at all. Nothing in the situation gave notice that the falling package had in it the potency of peril to persons thus removed. Negligence is not actionable unless it involves the invasion of a legally protected interest, the violation of a right... The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension.

Anthony's Pier Four, Inc. v. HBC Associa.support_reasoning: The opinion is a complex commercial contract and Chapter 93A decision about breach of development agreements, good faith and fair dealing, expectancy damages, and related issues. It does not address negligence principles such as duty, breach, causation, or foreseeability, nor does it discuss a landlord or possessor’s tort duties to maintain safe premises or safety devices. Accordingly, it does not support the stated negligence/premises-liability proposition.
Anthony's Pier Four, Inc. v. HBC Associa.relevant_excerpt: “This case arises from two agreements… providing for HBC’s acquisition and development of Fan Pier… After a jury-waived trial, the judge ruled that Anthony’s violated the express terms of the agreements and the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing… We affirm the award of expectancy damages… We reverse so much of the judgment as denied G. L. c. 93A damages to HBC.”

Daley v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 35.raw_text: Daley v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 351 Mass. 532 (1967)
Daley v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 35.proposition: The foregoing list is representative of the governing legal landscape on negligence principles (duty, breach, causation, foreseeability) and landlord/possessor responsibilities to maintain safe premises and required safety devices.
Daley v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 35.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal homicide case dealing with the voluntariness and admissibility of a confession, evidentiary issues, jury instructions on consciousness of guilt, alibi, and degrees of murder. It does not analyze civil negligence principles (duty, breach, causation, foreseeability) or landlord/possessor obligations to maintain safe premises or safety devices. Accordingly, it cannot serve as authority for the premises-liability negligence landscape described in the proposition.
Daley v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., 35.relevant_excerpt: The short answer to each assignment of error is that the trial judge, after the relevant voir dire examinations (see fn. 2), and the jury, after hearing the testimony before them, were not required to believe Rogers’ unsupported testimony tending to show that his confessions were not voluntary. The judge, and the jury as triers of the facts, heard and saw the police witnesses and Rogers. It was for them to appraise the sharply conflicting testimony.

Tobin v. Commonwealth, 372 Mass. 25 (197.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns procedural and evidentiary requirements under Massachusetts General Laws c. 123A for committing a prisoner as a sexually dangerous person. It does not address negligence principles such as duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, nor landlord/possessor responsibilities to maintain safe premises or safety devices. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition claimed.
Tobin v. Commonwealth, 372 Mass. 25 (197.relevant_excerpt: “A brief description of the statutory procedure for the determination and commitment of SDPs under G. L. c. 123A, § 6, reveals the central importance of this report.… A report by two psychiatrists which ‘clearly indicates’ that a person is an SDP remains, however, a statutory prerequisite to a petition for commitment. In the absence of such a report, the Commonwealth did not, and cannot, file a petition for commitment of the defendant.”

Meehan v. Shaughnessy, 373 Mass. 506 (19.proposition: The foregoing list is representative of the governing legal landscape on negligence principles (duty, breach, causation, foreseeability) and landlord/possessor responsibilities to maintain safe premises and required safety devices.
Meehan v. Shaughnessy, 373 Mass. 506 (19.support_reasoning: The case is a criminal prosecution under the Massachusetts conflict-of-interest statute (G.L. c. 268A) involving a city engineer’s financial interest in a real estate development. It analyzes statutory elements of conflict of interest, speedy trial, admissibility of prior recorded testimony, and reasonable doubt instructions; it does not address tort negligence principles (duty, breach, causation, foreseeability) or landlord/possessor premises-liability or safety-device obligations. Therefore, it does not support the stated proposition about negligence and landlord responsibilities.
Meehan v. Shaughnessy, 373 Mass. 506 (19.relevant_excerpt: The statute, G. L. c. 268A, § 17 (a), provides: “No municipal employee shall, otherwise than as provided by law for the proper discharge of official duties, directly or indirectly receive or request compensation from anyone other than the city or town or municipal agency in relation to any particular matter in which the same city or town is a party or has a direct and substantial interest.” It is beyond question that the evidence warranted findings that the defendant was a “municipal employee,” that he received an economic benefit from persons other than the city…

Foisie v. Worcester Ins. Co., 409 Mass..raw_text: Foisie v. Worcester Ins. Co., 409 Mass. 603 (1991)
Foisie v. Worcester Ins. Co., 409 Mass..proposition: The foregoing list is representative of the governing legal landscape on negligence principles (duty, breach, causation, foreseeability) and landlord/possessor responsibilities to maintain safe premises and required safety devices.
Foisie v. Worcester Ins. Co., 409 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns judicial discipline and the Commission on Judicial Conduct’s authority, standards of proof, evidentiary rules, and assessment of a judge’s misconduct. It does not address common-law negligence principles (duty, breach, causation, foreseeability) or landlord/possessor premises-liability or safety-device obligations. Therefore it cannot be cited as representative authority on those negligence or landlord duties issues.
Foisie v. Worcester Ins. Co., 409 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The Commission then issued to the court its report and recommendations. The Commission accepted and adopted all of the hearing officer’s findings and his conclusion that the Judge had violated several separate canons of the Code of Judicial Conduct. Based on this conclusion, the Commission recommended the following sanctions: a public censure, a $25,000 fine, a permanent injunction barring the Judge from either sitting in Dorchester District Court or hearing criminal and juvenile cases, a public apology, and the public release of its report and appendices.

Shea v. Gowriappan, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 13.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is a concurring opinion in a criminal case about the harmlessness of admitting a drug certificate in light of a defendant’s stipulation. It does not discuss negligence, duty, breach, causation, foreseeability, landlord obligations, or premises liability. Therefore, it cannot serve as authority for the stated negligence and landlord/possessor responsibilities proposition.
Shea v. Gowriappan, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 13.relevant_excerpt: "I join the court’s opinion in full on the understanding that the defendant’s entry into the stipulation alone rendered the otherwise-unconstitutional admission of the certificate of drug analysis harmless beyond a reasonable doubt. See Commonwealth v. Charles, 456 Mass. 378, 383 (2010) ... I do not read the court’s references to the defendant’s testimony to disturb our recent holding in Commonwealth v. Mendes, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 474, 480-481 (2010) ... that they therefore can not ‘form the basis for concluding that the admission of [a drug] certificate of analysis was harmless.’"
